newsitem.title: INDIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - August 16.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - August 16.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indian business and political stories in leading newspapers prepared for REUTERS by Business News and Information Services Pvt Ltd, New Delhi Tel:3326806, 3326813, 3326849 Fax:+91-11-3351006 E-mail: biznis@giasdl01.vsnl.net.in
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
TOP STORIES
The Times Of India
GUJRAL CALLS FOR FIGHT AGAINST CORRUPTION

Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral Friday called for a new movement against the corrupt. Addressing the nation from the ramparts of the Red Fort on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of India's independence, he said both givers and takers of bribe must be socially boycotted.
The Economic Times
RESERVE BANK TO GIVE WEEKLY DATA ON FOREX INTERVENTION
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) will release weekly data on its intervention in the foreign exchange market. This may help to curb excessive speculation, Deputy Governor Y.V. Reddy said.
AUTO COMPANIES MAY GET 6-MONTH IMPORT LICENCE The

The Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) may give a six month long import licence to auto makers until the cabinet committee on foreign investment approves streamlined export rules for multinational auto makers. The Commerce Ministry has sent the new policy proposal to the cabinet committee. The committee's approval is required before production begins, officials said. The streamlined policy will help auto majors like Honda and Volvo sign new memoranda of understanding with the DGFT. Its aim is to make India a major base of car exports in the region, officials said.
Financial Express
MANGALORE REFINERY PLANS $125 MLN GLOBAL ISSUE

The Mangalore Refinery and Petrochemicals has firmed up plans to launch a $100 million Global Depository Receipt (GDR) issue by the first quarter of 1998. It will have a greenshoe option to retain another $25 million. Company sources said leading foreign institutional investors were already making presentations to lead-manage the issue. The proceeds of the GDR issue will finance the refinery's capacity expansion plans. The Aditya Birla group and the HPCL who are its partners will inject 3.64 billion rupees each as their contribution to the expansion.
COLGATE-PALMOLIVE PLANS TO DOUBLE TURNOVER

Colgate-Palmolive (India) has announced plans to double its turnover by the year 2000 through strategic investments in business building, product diversification and market development. It plans to invest in infrastructure, technology and organisational effectiveness to enhance its market leadership and penetrate the oral care market. It is setting up a manufacturing facility for dicalcium phosphate in Aurangabad. The company also plans to strengthen its distribution reach, particularly in the rural market. It recently forayed into the household care market with its international product, Axion dish washing paste.
The Observer
AGRICULTURAL REFORMS ON THE ANVIL

Prime Minister Gujral on Friday announced a series of measures to bring the agriculture sector under the ongoing economic reforms. The stress will be on bringing in new technologies to promote dry-farm landing in areas where there is less rainfall, Gujral said.
Business Line
OVERSEAS FINANCE FIRMS SEEK ASSURANCE ON SAFE RUPEE LEVEL

Foreign financial institutions have sought an assurance from the Reserve Bank that the rupee will be contained at safe levels before they place any fresh investment proposal before the bourse regulator, the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI).
